column2: OK
column3: I had kind of conceptualized that Joss Whedon post along the lines of â€œhere are some random thoughts that Iâ€™m gonna store behind a cut in case a few people are interested
column4: â€ not expecting so many people to reblog it. But since there was so much interest
column5: I ended up thinking about it more. And the direction my thinking took me in was this: what is it that women find attractive in male and female characters
column6: and to what extent does this match up with what men assume that women find attractive in these characters? Hereâ€™s the thing: I honestly do not believe that Joss Whedon understands himself as writing for an exclusively male audience. I believe that he thinks to himself: â€œWow! This is so great! Iâ€™m writing for girls
column8: Iâ€™m writing the characters that women want!â€ (For one thing
column9: this is the line that has been fed to him by the media as a positive and important aspect of his work.) There are tons of male writers/directors who are very open about the fact that they are not interested in the female audience. (David Goyer comes to mind.) But Joss Whedon is not one of them. So what is going on with the disconnect between what he understands himself to be doing and what we see him doing? This disconnect doesnâ€™t just have to do with female characters
column10: either. Iâ€™m reminded of that Tumblr post that compares two magazine covers featuring Hugh Jackman: a menâ€™s magazine on which he appears bulging-veined
column12: and sort of terrifying and weird
column13: and a womenâ€™s magazine on which he appears as a slim
column14: athletic guy smiling and wearing a sweater. Anyone who reads comics is familiar with this weirdness: comics heroes are often depicted as nightmarishly hyper-muscled
column16: this trend grew more and more exaggerated as women became more and more nominally liberatedâ€” that is
column17: as they should have been more and more able to communicate what they wanted
column18: including what they wanted from men.) Hyper-masculinity is almost always framed in terms of being attractiveâ€” to women or
column20: to other menâ€” and sometimes even talked about in the same breath as â€œthe female gaze.â€ Yet
column21: as that Tumblr post points out
column22: while â€œthe female gazeâ€ is attracted by things like a naked
column23: sweaty Chris Evans or Idris Elba
column24: itâ€™s also attracted by things like: men smiling in sweaters
column26: barefoot fragile Sebastian Stan in the rain onÂ Political Animals
column30: and a whole bunch of weird stuff on Ao3 that I donâ€™t even wanna get into. And thatâ€™s just â€œthe female gaze as it pertains to men.â€Â  But think about whether men would agree that this is what women find attractive in men. Imagine a menâ€™s magazine that offers tips on being attractive to women that include: looking fragile
column35: being intensely interested in gorgeous clothes
column37: etc. This is hard to imagine. In fact
column38: these are characteristics that are typically characterized asÂ not ideal for men
column39: because they are coded asÂ feminine.Â Yet theyâ€™re also not only traits that are commonly attractive to women
column40: but are generallyÂ accepted as commonly attractive to women
column41: if one looks at â€œwomenâ€™sâ€ entertainment (romantic comedies
column43: anything in which Hugh Grant appears).Â  What Iâ€™m getting at is that there is a division between what attracts women and what men accept/permit as attracting women. Men are engaged in a constant enforcement of heteronormativity
column44: a policing of womenâ€™s desire and their own accession to it. What women want is subordinate to what men decide that women want
column45: and the latter is then culturally broadcast as the ideological â€œwhat women wantâ€ that becomes accepted. This is true also in the case of female characters. What do women want in female characters? Well
column47: a lot of usÂ just want female characters for the love of God.Â But specifically: some of the most popular current female characters in comics/MCU fandom are: Natasha Romanoff
column48: in a movie (Cap 2) where she only briefly appeared in a sexy bodysuit and instead spent most of her time wearing jeans and a hoodie
column50: having a complex narrative about salvation
column52: not to mention the down-to-earth Phil Noto comics depiction
column53: who even (GASP) sometimes wears a ponytail; Peggy Carter
column54: a 1940s secret agent with little patience for men; Kamala Khan
column55: a teenage Pakistani-American girl who writes fan fiction and wears a modest homemade costume; Darcy Lewis
column58: and not a superhero; the lady scientists of the MCU (Jane Foster
column60: Betty Ross)â€¦ I could go on. But what do men apparently believe that women want in female characters? Well
column61: going by Joss Whedon: superheroines who wear catsuits
column65: fragile and unstable girl-women with superpowers beyond their controlâ€¦ oh
column66: wait. Thatâ€™s it. Expanding beyond Whedon
column67: the most common characteristics tend to be: aggressively sexy
column69: beats up bad men but is secretly vulnerable. I discussed already one potential reason this is attractive to men (see my previous post); my issue here is: this is not what women want
column70: but it is what men believe that women want
column71: because it is what they have been told by other men that women want.Â  Once again
column74: Â invisibilizedâ€” in that men deny or are oblivious to its existence) in favor of the ideological construct of â€œwhat women want
column75: â€ which is determined and enforced by men. Men genuinely believe that they know what women want
column76: and are earnest in their attempts to explain â€œwhat women wantâ€ to women. They are deeply confused
column77: becauseÂ of course they know what women want! Right? They are unable to see that they are selling a version of â€œwhat women wantâ€ is essentially â€œwhat it would be attractive to men for women to want.â€Â  That is the center of this thing:Â everything revolves aroundÂ what men want.Â What type of female heroine would be most attractive to men? If she has to be strong
column78: what type of strength would men find attractive? How can she be â€œfeministâ€ but still attractive to men? This seems obvious
column79: yet men seem to find it invisible. One of the most interesting angles from which to consider this is that of the queer/lesbian woman. That is the viewpoint that isÂ most invisibilized in this discussion
column80: because it simply has no relevance or importance to menâ€™s desires. The woman who is not sexually available to men does not exist within a system that assesses womenâ€™s value based on sexual availability to men. The gay male gaze is comprehensible
column81: because it can conform to existing ideas about the male bodyâ€™s desirability (though it does not always). Indeed
column82: the gay male gaze is often preferable to the female gaze
column83: because it sidesteps the problematic female perspective. The lesbian gaze
column85: is fundamentally incomprehensible. It is the divide-by-zero point of the system. What does a woman want if she doesnâ€™t want men and doesnâ€™t want what-men-want-from-women? This is the perspective from which itâ€™s easiest to see the bizarreness of whatâ€™s going on
column86: the degree to which it is all centrally tied up with men. This is
column88: the reason that itâ€™sÂ so important for women to have creative control over projects. For women to write
column90: direct. As long as men dominate these positions
column91: representations of what women want will be filtered through them. Itâ€™s not accidental that two of the most popular female comics characters among women (Kamala Khan and Captain Marvel) are being written by women. We need female creators; we need female voices.
